section.title: Objective and Overview
section.para: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create a Spacecraft and a Propagator, and then propagate the spacecraft to the desired position - in this example, to orbit perigee, which is the minimum distance to Earth. The meaning of the term "propagate" here is to simulate the spacecraft orbital motion. The basic steps in this tutorial are:

listitem.para: Configure theSpacecraft and define its epoch and orbital elements.
Configure the Propagator.
Modify the default OrbitView to visualize the spacecraft trajectory.
Modify the Propagate command to to propagate the spacecraft to the perigee.
Run the mission and analyze the results.

section.title: Configure the Spacecraft
section.para: In this section, you will rename a Spacecraft and set the Spacecraft's initial epoch and classical orbital elements. You'll need GMAT open, with the Default Mission loaded. To load the Default Mission click New Mission in the Toolbar or start a new GMAT session.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, right-click DefaultSC, and select Rename.
In the Rename dialog box, type Sat .
Click OK.

section.title: Set the Spacecraft Epoch
section.para: Now you will set the initial epoch of Sat.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, double-click on Sat. Click the Orbit tab if it is not already selected.
In the Epoch Format box, select UTCGregorian. You'll see the value in the Epoch field change to the UTC Gregorian epoch format.
In in the Epoch field, type 22 Jul 2014 11:29:10.811.
Click Apply to save these changes.

section.title: Set the Keplerian Orbital Elements
section.para: To set the Keplerian oribital elements of Sat:

listitem.para: In the StateType box select Keplerian . In Elements list you will see the GUI reconfigure to display to the Keplerian representation.
In the SMA box, type 83474.318.
In the ECC box, type 0.89652.
In the INC box, type 12.4606.
In the RAAN box, type 112.8362.
In the AOP box, type 218.9805.
In the TA box, type 180.
Compare your configuration with below and fix any differences, and click OK.

section.para: At this point, save your work to the disk: In the Toolbar , click the Save button. If this is the first time you have saved the mission, you'll be prompted to provide a name and location for the file.

section.title: Configure the Propagator
section.para: In this section you'll rename the Propagator, and configure the force model.

section.title: Rename the Propagator
section.para: Here you'll rename the propagator with a more descriptive name:

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, double-click DefaultProp, and select Rename.
In the Rename dialog box, type LowEarthProp.
Click OK.

section.title: Configure the Force Model
section.para: Now configure the force model. For this tutorial you will use an Earth 10x10 spherical harmonic model, Jacchia-Roberts atmospheric model, solar radiation pressure, and point mass perturbations from the Sun and Moon.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, double-click LowEarthProp,
In the Gravity list, type 10 both the Degree box.
Type 10 in the Order box.
In Atmosphere Model box, select JacchiaRoberts.
Click the Select button next to the Point Masses text box. This opens the CelestialBodySelect dialog box.
In the Available Bodies list, click Sun, then click -> to add Sunto the Selected Bodies list.
Add Moon (named Luna in GMAT) using the same procedure above.
Compare your configuration with the figure below and fix any differences.
Click Use SolarRadiation Pressure to toggle it on.
Compare your LowEarthProp configuration with below, fix any discrepencies, and click OK.

section.title: Configuring the Orbit View Plot
section.para: Below you will configure an Orbit View plot so you can visualize Sat and its trajectory. The orbit of Sat is highly eccentric. To view the entire orbit in the plot, we need to adjust the settings of DefaultOrbitView.

listitem.para: In the Resources Tree, click on DefaultOrbitView.
In the three boxes next to ViewPointVector, type the values 30000, -5000, and 5000 respectively.
In the Drawing Options list, uncheck DrawXY Plane.
Compare your DefaultOrbitView configuration with below, fix any discrepencies, and click OK.

section.title: Configure the Propagate Command
section.para: This is the last step in the tutorial before running the mission. Below you will configure a Propagate command to propagate (model the motion of) Sat to orbit perigee.

listitem.para: Click the Mission tab to bring the Mission Tree to the foreground.
Double-click on Propagate1.
In the Stopping Conditions list, right click the (...) button next to Sat.ElapsedSecs to bring up the Parameter Select Dialog
In the Object list, select Sat if it is not already selected. This directs GMAT to associate the stopping condition with the spacecraft Sat.
In the Object Properties list, double-click Periapsis to add it to the Selected Values list as shown in .
Click OK.
Compare your Propagate1 configuration with below, fix any discrepencies, and click OK.

section.title: Running the Mission
section.para: Congratulations, you have now configured your first GMAT mission and are ready to run the mission and analyze the results.

listitem.para: Click the Save button in the Toolbar to save your mission.
Click the Run button in the Toolbar.

section.para: You will see GMAT propagate the orbit and stop at orbit periapsis. below illustrates what you should see after correctly completing this tutorial. Here are a few things you can try to explore the results of this tutorial:

listitem.para: Manipulate the Orbit View plot using your mouse to orient the trajectory so that you can to verify that at the final location the spacecraft is at perigee.
Click the Mission Tab to bring the Mission Tree to the foreground.
Left-click on Propagate1 and select Command Summary to see data on the final state of Sat.
What values for longitude and latitude do you see for Sat.
